									<article id="post-3780" class="post-3780 post type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry category-disability-disability-advocacy category-infectious-disease-vaccines tag-autism tag-disabilities tag-language-matters tag-vaccines post_format-post-format-image">
	<div class="picture">
		<a href="http://thescientificparent.org/vaccines-dont-cause-autism-but-thats-not-the-point/"><img width="1180" height="635" src="http://i1.wp.com/thescientificparent.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Greenburg-Autism-Speaks-Listen.png?resize=1180%2C635" class="attachment-full-thumb size-full-thumb wp-post-image" alt="Greenburg Autism Speaks Listen" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/thescientificparent.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Greenburg-Autism-Speaks-Listen.png?zoom=2&resize=1180%2C635 2360w, http://i1.wp.com/thescientificparent.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Greenburg-Autism-Speaks-Listen.png?zoom=3&resize=1180%2C635 3540w" sizes="(max-width: 1180px) 100vw, 1180px" /></a>
	</div>
	<div class="post-header clearfix">
		<h2 class="title"><a href="http://thescientificparent.org/vaccines-dont-cause-autism-but-thats-not-the-point/">Vaccines Don’t Cause Autism, But That’s Not the Point</a></h2>		
		
		<span class="meta"> 
			By <a href="http://thescientificparent.org/author/guest-author/" title="Posts by Leslie Waghorn" class="author url fn" rel="author">Leslie Waghorn</a>		</span> 
		<span class="meta"><i class="fa fa-calendar-o"></i>March 7, 2016		<i class="fa fa-comment-o"></i><a href="http://thescientificparent.org/vaccines-dont-cause-autism-but-thats-not-the-point/#comments"><span class="dsq-postid" data-dsqidentifier="3780 http://thescientificparent.org/?p=3780">25 Comments</span></a></span>
		<br>
		<div class="post-bottom clearfix">
    <span class="meta">Share: </span>
    <a rel="nofollow" href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=http://thescientificparent.org/vaccines-dont-cause-autism-but-thats-not-the-point/" title="Share on Facebook" target="_blank">
        <i class="fa fa-facebook"></i>
    </a>
    <a rel="nofollow" href="http://twitter.com/home?status=Vaccines+Don%26%238217%3Bt+Cause+Autism%2C+But+That%26%238217%3Bs+Not+the+Point-http://thescientificparent.org/vaccines-dont-cause-autism-but-thats-not-the-point/" title="Tweet This!" target="_blank">
        <i class="fa fa-twitter"></i>
    </a>
    <a href="http://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=http://thescientificparent.org/vaccines-dont-cause-autism-but-thats-not-the-point/&media=http://thescientificparent.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Greenburg-Autism-Speaks-Listen.png" title="Pin this!" target="_blank">
        <i class="fa fa-pinterest"></i>
    </a>
    <a href="https://plus.google.com/share?url=http://thescientificparent.org/vaccines-dont-cause-autism-but-thats-not-the-point/" title="Share on Google+" target="_blank">
        <i class="fa fa-google-plus"></i>
    </a>
</div>
	
	</div>
		

	<div class="post-content clearfix">
		<div class="thecontent">
			
	

		<p><span style="color: #808080;"><em> </em></span>When I was studying vaccine safety communication in grad school, I didn’t really think about autism as being a part of the conversation. That correlation had been disproved so thoroughly time and time again, I thought about autism only in a statistical sense. I thought of it in terms of t-tests and chi-squares.</p>
<p>Yes, I had loved ones that were on the autism spectrum or had children that were to varying degrees and I appreciated the challenges they faced, but vaccines were never part of our conversation, and why would they be?  <a href="https://www.aap.org/en-us/Documents/immunization_vaccine_studies.pdf" target="_blank">Hundreds of studies with hundreds of thousands of data points</a> both retrospective and prospective, and the correlation had been disproven.</p>
<p>At times when we’re faced with a parent or a friend that has a concern about something, we try to allay their concerns instead of addressing whether those concerns were valid to begin with.  In a clinical setting providers have a short period of time to address parents’ concerns and having a larger conversation about risk and what it means to have a child with autism really means just isn’t feasible.  The conversation gets shortened to simply “vaccines don’t cause autism.”  I cringe to admit it now, but I was once part of that problem.</p>
<p>As Julia and I say over and over again on this site, language matters, and I didn’t realize how much my comments could have hurt some people. But as Julia and I also say, it’s OK and important to change your mind with new information. This is the story of how I came to change how I think about vaccines and autism.</p>
<p><span id="more-3780"></span></p>
<p>Answering the same questions from parents time and time again can be exhausting.  It can become difficult to find a new way to say the same thing a different way.  When a parent would express fear about vaccinating because of the perceived risk of autism, I would use phrases like, “parents don’t need to be afraid that vaccines cause autism,” and “the fear that vaccines cause autism.” I was hearing that a parent was afraid and I was addressing that fear. In my mind the message was cut and dry: vaccines don’t cause autism. Often in the science community we can tend to view language as factual instead of contextual. Vaccines don’t cause autism, that’s true, but what’s the underlying concern about autism. Why is it something to be afraid of?</p>
<p>It wasn’t until I was driving home from class one day and was listening to C-SPAN radio. I was in my mid-20s and living in Washington, DC. This would seem weird anywhere else in America, but in DC it’s perfectly normal. The panel discussion being broadcast was teens and adults with autism and how federal funding could better support them. As the show closed, the moderator asked if anyone on the panel felt a vaccine had caused their autism.</p>
<p>Silence.</p>
<p>One teen panelist spoke up, “no, but it hurts that you would ask that question.”</p>
<p>The moderator’s tone softened, he apologized and asked why. I’m going to paraphrase the boy’s response because it has been several years and for the life of me I have not been able to find a transcript of this event anywhere, which has driven me to madness. If anyone from C-SPAN reads this and knows the talk I’m referring to, please send me a transcript! The panelist’s response was incredibly moving and I wish I could give him credit for it and do his response justice.</p>
<p>As I recall his response was, “because it makes me feel like I’m damaged or broken, when I’m not. I was born this way. My brain just works differently than most other people’s. When people talk about vaccines and autism it makes me feel like I’m not a person but a ‘bad result.’ It reminds me that no one wants a kid like me and parents will risk their kid’s lives and everyone else’s just to make sure their kid doesn’t turn out like me.”</p>
<p>There was silence on the radio. By this time I’d pulled into our parking spot at home and sat in the car in silence as well. It was a moment of epiphany.</p>
<p>Oh bleep, I thought. I’ve never thought of it like that.</p>
<p>The panelist’s words were so loaded and unfiltered. He was speaking from the heart and I could imagine the pain he felt when he described that some parents would rather have their children die than turn out like him. That is an incredible and completely unnecessary burden for any child to carry around, yet any time vaccines were discussed, those assumptions were coded in language.</p>
<p>The boy’s response was so moving and reframed the vaccines and autism debate in my mind so completely, I felt incredible shame for even joking about vaccines and autism and rightfully so. Embedded in my comments was the same coded language the panelist spoke of. The implications of my language were that autism was so terrible it was to be feared, it was something to be avoided at all costs and most of all it made someone different in a way that wasn’t positive.</p>
<p>I changed my language after that. I’m very, very aware of how I talk about vaccines and autism affects those who have autism. I see people in the science-based community make these statements or jokes sometimes about vaccines and autism and I cringe. Around October I start seeing the jokes, “just got my flu shot, so far no signs of autism!” I know there’s no malicious intent towards people with autism, but the outcome is the same.  They make them with the best of intentions, unaware of how their language may make those with autism feel.</p>
<p>I now speak up whenever I feel the person would be receptive to hearing how their language could be interpreted. Most of the time I see the light bulb go off in their head and they say they’d never thought of it like that before and will be aware of it going forward. Sometimes the person pushes back and says it’s just a joke and they’re talking about how people perceive autism, not people with autism themselves.</p>
<p>One thing is for certain, I’m careful about how I talk about vaccines and autism now. I may still get the language wrong from time-to-time, but I’m doing my best to make sure my language is respectful.</p>
<p> </p>

    <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-629">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-629" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-629">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-629">Midori Ryans</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-629" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-629" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Thank-you so much for speaking out against something that hurts us so much, you have no idea how rare it is.</p>
<p>To note though: on the use of language, we are “autistic” – we don’t “have autism” – as being Autistics is an integral part of who we are – or at least for myself, and most Autistics I know or communicate with. “With autism” or “have autism” suggests that autism is some secondary, separate from us, and thus, removable. But it weaves itself into how we view the world, how we move through it, and how we interact with it: that’s called diversity, not disease. As you said, use of language is more important than many people give it credit for.</p>
<p>I nitpick only because you suggested an openness to know this.<br />
And regardless, this article itself is already a huge step in representing autism rights, and I am so very grateful. 🙂 Thank-you.</p>
</div>
        </div>

    <ul class="children">
    <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-635">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-635" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-635">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-635">Scientific Parent</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-635" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-635" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Hi Midori – Thank you so much for your comment, we really appreciate the feedback.  </p>
<p>I actually struggled with this issue when writing this post, so I reached out to a colleague that works in disability advocacy.  She advised that it was more respectful to use people-centric language, putting the person first and the condition second.  She felt that this acknowledged individuals as people and did not limit their definition to their condition. With that said, my colleague is neurotypical and wasn’t speaking from personal experience. </p>
<p>Comments like yours help us better understand each other and move the dialogue forward.  Thank you for letting me know that “autistic” is preferred.  Julia and I will make sure we use this language going forward.  Thank you. – LW</p>
</div>
        </div>

    <ul class="children">
    <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-687">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-687" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-687">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-687">Joseph Newman</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-687" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-687" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>One of the biggest problems with person first language, other than that it isn’t thought of as useful for other disabilities, or the grammar of the thing, is that it assumes you have to tell the audience that we are people. If that’s the first thing you have to do, the problem is a lot bigger than you can cover. Getting back to the other part, the grammar of it isn’t that great either. Adverb goes before noun. And aside from that, you don’t say “person with blindness” or “person with deafness” or “person with blackness” or “person with womanhood”, you use blind person, deaf person, black person, and woman. Nowhere else other than autism and some similar conditions do you see anyone advocating for person first language. It’s a bit insulting that so many people think it is proper.</p>
</div>
        </div>

        <div id="dsq-comment-body-630" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-630" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I don’t understand this. Waghorn states that a panel moderator asked if anyone on the panel felt a vaccine had caused their autism. Someone said that it hurt that the moderator asked that question. Waghorn then says that with this, she realized that she had to be careful about the language she used when talking about the vaccine-autism matter, and as an example, mentioned people making jokes when getting their flu shot. Waitaminute—what does making jokes when getting a flu shot have to do with the mere **question** of whether anyone with autism felt that a vaccine had caused their autism?? What does that have to do with “jokes”? In what way is the “language” in which that question was asked inappropriate? Because some with autism feel that they are made to feel like a “bad result” means that that question is wrong? How does Waghorn figure this? The question is a perfectly valid one, and a necessary one to ask, just as all questions in science must be asked. While it’s unfortunate that anyone with autism may feel bad about it, it in no way makes it wrong to ask that question.</p>
</div>
        </div>

    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
    <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-636">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-636" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-636">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-636">Brianne Kirkpatrick</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-636" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-636" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I am a genetic counselor in my professional life, and I’m the mom of a child with a neurodevelopmental disorder called dyspraxia which has some overlap with ASD. I try to be careful with my language at all times because I embrace differences of all types, but as a health professional I also feel like my job is to provide information when it can be useful. Take, for example, folic acid in the pre-conception and early prenatal period. Studies have shown the effectiveness of folic acid supplementation in reducing the risk a baby will develop a neural tube defect (like spina bifida). But I worry that publicly espousing folic acid supplementation somehow makes people living with a neural tube defect or the parents of a child with an NTD feel hurt or made to feel like a failure. It is very challenging, and I still haven’t figured out a way to provide education or information that has an impact at the population level without being taken as personal affront at the individual level. This story is another example of this challenge we have in language about different abilities and communicating information obtained from epidemiological studies. Of course there is a HUGE difference here — that of the lack of evidence supporting any connection between vaccines and autism compared to the overwhelming evidence of folic acid and reduction in NTD risk — but the underlying question here is the same: Is it possible to talk about “preventing” disability without insinuating that disability is something people should want to avoid?</p>
</div>
        </div>

    <ul class="children">
    <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-703">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-703" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-703">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-703">Kmarie</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-703" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-703" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I have Severe dyspraxia and Autism. If you want to know what it could be like for your daughter with Dyspraxia as an adult I wrote about it here: <a href="http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2015/02/dyspraxia-struggle-of-adult-with.html" rel="nofollow">http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2015/02/dyspraxia-struggle-of-adult-with.html</a> I actually struggle more with my Dyspaxia limitations than any other difference in brain wiring…</p>
<p>I think your last question, while somewhat valid, is focusing on the wrong aspect. Is there a way instead for the world to embrace autism and dyspraxia so that we can be our own unique way of BEING in the world and still be viewed as contributing members of society? Is there a way to minimize the painful parts of life but still value that a person IS the way they are? Is there a way to help contain seizures which are NOT autism but can accompany a different brain scheme? Is there a way to prolong the life of someone with Down Syndrome and stop the heart defect part of it without changing whom they are which in essence a big part of their own genetic make up IS the difference in chromosome? This is Nuerodiverse dialogue…our world has come a long way in bigotry and racism- now it’s time to slowly change our rhetoric regarding ableism. You are right- language is important and we all need to educate ourselves further by reading stories of those who actually understand their personality and brain and embrace them:) </p>
<p> To speak about avoiding “disability” and to sum it down to that is to be a huge partaker in ableism. See all the links in this post for more if one wants to educate themselves so not to parake in the unintentional ignorance…which I was also a part of myself even having a different brain wiring…I understand it’s normal but when there is a chance to read the links and be educated from those that belong to these groups of people I highly suggest that route: <a href="http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2014/08/autistics-dont-need-your-awareness-and.html" rel="nofollow">http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2014/08/autistics-dont-need-your-awareness-and.html</a></p>
</div>
        </div>

    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
    <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-710">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-710" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-710">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-710">Kmarie</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-710" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-710" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I have dyspraxia: <a href="http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2015/02/dyspraxia-struggle-of-adult-with.html" rel="nofollow">http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2015/02/dyspraxia-struggle-of-adult-with.html</a>  I wrote a comment in response to this before but it disappeared:) this is the short version:) I think that there is a difference between education and telling our stories. When we listen to the stories of those with the actual conditions themselves- and what they want – then we naturally  become educated and science can follow instead of vice versa. While well meaning- some of the very ‘cures’ developed trample the essence and individuality of a person. We can find ways to help heart defects without negating the special aspects of neurological conditioning. We can help the world be kinder to sensory stimulation and to tone down the extraverted nature of everything without using ABA therapy to stop behaviours that the majority wish to control in the minority …but these things are huge cultural changes- I guess everything starts with the individual.</p>
</div>
        </div>

    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->
    <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-637">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-637" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-637">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-637">Amy Harrington</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-637" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-637" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Love this article! I don’t want to click “you got it wrong” because you got it so right! However… I would like to ask a question and start a conversation. Autism is a natural human variant. It is part of our evolution, I would like to suggest that the neurotoxins in vaccines do have a serious impact on the children (already) on the spectrum. It may very well be the cause of regression and developmental growth. Do you think its what turns neurological differences into the disabilities autistics deal with today? Can we view vaccines and autism from a different perspective?</p>
</div>
        </div>

    <ul class="children">
    <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-639">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-639" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-639">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-639">Jodie Wirth</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-639" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-639" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Your response stands out to me because I have more than one family member on the spectrum. My third son developed well until 12 months of age, before experiencing developmental regression that was temporally associated with him receiving the varicella vaccine. I’ve asked myself many times whether it is possible the vaccine caused the autism or if it’s possible he already had autism but the vaccine caused the developmental regression which led to him being intellectually disabled. There is also a chance the vaccine played no part and the timing was coincidental but the cause has not been identified.  I’ve also wondered whether vaccinations could have played a role in the other family members having autism even though they are high functioning.  I think this is a conversation that needs to be had and it’s great that you brought it up. This idea that it is offensive to see autism as a condition that we want to stop is offensive to some of us struggling with the challenges of raising someone with autism and intellectual disability who we will not always be around to care for. I understand what this boy was saying and can understand why he would feel this way in his situation. Another perspective on it comes from my 17 year old son diagnosed with Asperger’s. He does not hesitate in saying he would get rid of autism if he could even though he knows he has it himself. I don’t think he says this because of his own personal challenges but the challenges he sees his severely affected brother face and the challenges those of us who love and care for him face due to his condition. I don’t want to be without any of my kids but if I could eradicate autism without eradicating the people who have it I would in a heartbeat,  for the benefit of the severely affected and their loved ones.</p>
</div>
        </div>

    <ul class="children">
    <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-681">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-681" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-681">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-681">Agilemind</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-681" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-681" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>There is no evidence that vaccines have any effect in causing or exacerbating autism or other developmental disabilities. Autism is primarily a genetic disease. If your family has multiple people on the spectrum it is even more likely to be genetic in origin – current evidence suggests many genetic variants can cause the disorder and frequently multiple variants must combine in a single individual (hence the more scattered family patterns).</p>
</div>
        </div>

    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
    <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-705">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-705" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-705">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-705">sparrowrose</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-705" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-705" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>“If I could eradicate autism without eradicating the people who have it…”</p>
<p>The thing is, you can’t. Autistics without our autism would be completely different people. As Jom Sinclair so eloquently put it:</p>
<p>“This is what we hear when you pray for a cure. This is what we know, when you tell us of your fondest hopes and dreams for us: that your greatest wish is that one day we will cease to be, and strangers you can love will move in behind our faces.”</p>
<p>Like your son, I wept often and wish for autism to be lifted away from me. I would have given up 60 IQ points in exchange for being like hose around me.</p>
<p>Then some fellow Autistics lovingly showed me (it took time; they were patient with me) how much better my life would be if I weren’t forced to cope with the world’s ableism every day.</p>
<p>Yes, many things would still be difficult for me. But with understanding and support, life would be better. I still would struggle to keep myself fed, but others would understand and help me eat. I still would struggle with hygeine, but rather than cruelly mock me for it, others would help me get that need met and be understanding when it wasn’t.</p>
<p>People would be less likely to talk circles around me, silence me, lack the patience to wait for me to communicate with them, shame me for the many things I can’t do.</p>
<p>Yes, I am disabled and need supports to survive and thrive, but in exchange I see great beauty in places others say they see nothing good. </p>
<p>My autistic brain makes me who I am. It is how I sense the world and make sense of the world. It is the source of my emotions and decisions. Everything I am comes from my autistic brain.</p>
<p>To make me not-autistic is to give me a different brain. With a different brain, there would no longer be a “me.” As Sinclair says, removing my autism would place a stranger behind my face. </p>
<p>Perhaps people in my life would love me more, but that thought is terrifying, because it would no longer be me they were loving.</p>
</div>
        </div>

    <ul class="children">
    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-708">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-708" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-708">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-708">Kmarie</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-708" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-708" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Yes…thank you for this comment. For some reason my two comments previously were erased but basically I pointed to the world’s ableism too. The blog Musings of An Aspie has wonderful perspectives to share. I am Autistic and I love who I am. My kids are too. There are ways to address seizures which are NOT autism but may accompany them – so yes, address the painful aspects that may shorten life in physical things- like heart defects in down syndrome but not that extra chromosome that makes the person special and is part of their genetic make up. Nueordiversity has a long way to go to acceptance…it’s the new civil rights frontier:)  I wrote about the autism vaccine thing years ago: <a href="http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2013/11/vaccinations-autism-heartbreak-and.html" rel="nofollow">http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2013/11/vaccinations-autism-heartbreak-and.html</a>   and here is my ‘coming out post’ <a href="http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2015/10/i-am-autistic-and-here-are-some-facts-i.html" rel="nofollow">http://worldwecreate.blogspot.ca/2015/10/i-am-autistic-and-here-are-some-facts-i.html</a></p>
</div>
        </div>

    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

    <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-656">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-656" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-656">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-656">verkMD</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-656" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-656" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>So, how do you now talk about the subject with parents who are afraid?  To be fair, even though that panelist was hurt by the question (and I understand the point), no one would choose this option for their child.  And most would do all they can to avoid it.<br />
How has this insight changed your practice?</p>
</div>
        </div>

    <ul class="children">
    <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-682">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-682" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-682">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-682">Scientific Parent</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-682" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-682" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Hi Verk,</p>
<p>I try to talk about what we know about autism in it’s own bubble, focusing on what we do know, while using plain language.  For example, if a parent tells me they’re nervous or afraid of vaccinating because they’ve heard it causes autism, my response is usually “the current research supports that autism is a genetic condition, genetic doesn’t necessarily mean inherited, but in some cases there appears to be a family history.  The research also supports that it is something that develops in utero.  It’s also important to remember that autism isn’t a singular condition with a variety of symptoms.  Research now supports that there are many different types of autism with varying degrees of symptoms and onset.”</p>
<p>If the parents press further (about 40% of the time) I discuss correlation vs causation as an extension of the last point. – LW</p>
</div>
        </div>

    </li><!-- #comment-## -->

    <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-672">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-672" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-672">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-672">Rosemary Edwards</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-672" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-672" class="dsq-comment-message"><p> First of all THANKYOU so much for writing this with so much honesty and integrity.  I who should have known better, considering live day to day with mental health issues and have been sectioned many times, .…….always rattling on about self embracement and that shame we feel not being ours but rather belonging to those who make us feel bad about who we are………</p>
<p>This morning I read an article that arrived from ‘Natural News’ an American site, I live in the UK, it talked all about the link between Autism ‘development’ and immunizations. Now I thought (obviously not thinking at all)….This must be important information for my Facebook page, . Luckily for me my wonderful sister  was on the phone to me as soon as it went live online, explained my error in posting this article, how harmful it was and impact it had. </p>
<p>To be totally honest I cried as I shamefully deleted it with all the hurt I could have unknowlingly caused. I was born with a different brain to, and all I have ever wanted is for people to accept me, love me and please stop judging me. </p>
</div>
        </div>

    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
    <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-684">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-684" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-684">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-684">Steph</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-684" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-684" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Fantastic article which hopefully will make people stop and think a little about the words they choose.<br />
As someone who isn’t autistic but does have a condition from birth I also find the popular comment from soon to be mums and dads “I don’t mind if it’s a boy or a girl, as long as it’s healthy” just as hurtful. It’s basically saying that anyone born “unhealthy” is a consolation prize and not worth as much as a perfect child. Of course we all hope that our kids and family live a long, healthy and happy life, but surely health is relative and happiness is the most important factor. Having a disability doesn’t have to mean that they won’t achieve this. Disability doesn’t have to = tragedy.</p>
</div>
        </div>

    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
    <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-690">
        <div id="dsq-comment-header-690" class="dsq-comment-header">
            <cite id="dsq-cite-690">
                <span id="dsq-author-user-690">lisa saab</span>
            </cite>
        </div>
        <div id="dsq-comment-body-690" class="dsq-comment-body">
            <div id="dsq-comment-message-690" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>This is how i describe my son with autism:<br />
When Tyler was born, he had an inexplicable piece of glitter stuck to his head for days. He was speaking in sentences at 1, and recognizing letters and sounds before 2. Friends would joke that he was reading, War and Peace, while their same age kids were barely speaking. I was bursting with pride at how smart my kid was. As he got older, we noticed he preferred to talk to adults over kids. He hated having his nails cut, hair cut, and clothes on. He had to have a particular blanket and tags had to be cut out of clothing. We’ve been through obsessions with space, the human body, Pokemon, and politics. There have been breakdowns over a broken scooter, an accidentally erased part in a video game, and numerous other, seemingly minor things. In the midst of this, the autism diagnosis. Not a surprise, but not what most parents want to hear.<br />
     So, what do you get with a kid with autism? You get someone that you can talk to, as an adult, from a young age. You get an insanely smart child that surprises you with his wit and humor on a daily basis. You get a sweet, lovable boy that still blows you kisses and hugs every day when he gets out of the car. You get a child that has more knowledge about most subjects than you do. You get someone who knows his opinions and has the confidence to stand up for what he believes in. You get a kid with the bravery to stand in front of his peers every year and answer questions about his “disability”. Most of all, you get a child that has added the sparkle and glitter to your life from the day he was born.<br />
Tyler Saab, you make autism cool. I love you and all your Dorito swag 🙂</p>
<p>#autismawareness</p>
</div>
        </div>

            <div id="dsq-comment-message-709" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>We have a long way to go to combat ableist remarks and the mentality of ‘disability’ in our culture.
